intro: Acer negundo var. variegatum, commonly known as the variegated box elder, is a deciduous tree native to North America. It is a variant of the box elder species, characterized by its striking variegated leaves that display white and yellow patterns. The tree typically grows to a height of 10–20 meters and has compound leaves with three to five leaflets. It produces small, yellowish-green flowers in the spring, followed by winged seeds that are dispersed by the wind. This plant thrives in full sun to partial shade and is often found in moist, well-drained soils.
